title: Ticket #4315: Python bindings should expose locking API
description:
We would like to have the locking API exposed via the python bindings (preferably through a python context manager, like we do with transaction).

HTCondor uses a special locking protocol that is not POSIX, involving taking POSIX locks in a special directory instead of taking the lock on the file itself.

If a python application needs to take a lock on a file (such as a read / write lock on a user log), we should add an API to do this in a straightforward manner to avoid racing with HTCondor.

I propose the following API: 

fd = open("/tmp/foo")
with htcondor.lock(fd, htcondor.LockType.WriteLock) as lock:
  fd.write("blah")

By using a context manager and not exposing something mutex-like, we help users avoid shooting themselves. Not bullet-proof, but it's better than nothing.

I would expect this is a highly-specialized feature, probably only used by CMS.
